name: lathyrus-latifolius
country-or-region-of-origin: Eastern Central & Southern Europe and NW. Africa
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
fruit-description: Fruits are a flattened, narrow legume with fleshy, round, green seeds. Young fruits and seeds (peas) are edible once cooked.
flower-description: Flowers have 5-15 petals. They are pea-like in elongated clusters and corolla is up to 1" in size. They can be magenta-purple, rose-pink, white, yellow, or blue in color. Inflorescence is a raceme, axillary. Peduncle length exceeds the length of leaves. They bloom in midsummer to fall.
leaf-description: Leaves are ternately compound with the 3rd leaflet being a 3-branched tendril. They are alternate, pinnately divided, and each has 2 or more leaflets and a terminal tendril. Leaflets are oblong to elliptic, acute, mucronate, cuneate, entire, 3-5 veined, blue-green, and up to 4" long. Stipules are persistent and leaflike.
stem-description: Stems are green, alate, and are either pubescent or glabrous. They have leafy wings.
poison-symptoms: TOXIC ONLY IF LARGE QUANTITIES EATEN.  "Lathyrism": paralysis, slow and weak pulse, shallow breathing, and convulsions, tremors, seizures and possibly death
